## -----------2020-2022------------

## International Crises ([CrisisEvents.org](https://www.CrisisEvents.org){target="_blank"})

::: {.panel-tabset .tabset-pills}

### Converting Text to Events

::: {.column-margin}
How do we perform statistics on history when it's locked in unstructured text?<br><br>
We introduce a measurement system for turning text into machine readable events.<br><br>
This example from the [Cuban Missile Crisis (1962)](https://www.crisisevents.org/196.html){target="_blank"} shows how our ontology applied by human coders turns each sentence into one or more explicit interactions.
:::
![](images/case_study_cuban_precision.png)

### Visualizing Timeseries-Networks

::: {.column-margin}
Multi-dimensional graphs that evolve over time are difficult to visualize. We introduce a crisis-map, which shows actors on individual timelines, with points representing unilateral events, and edges representing directed actions.
:::

![](images/paste-99AF2740.png)

### High-coverage Ontology

::: {.column-margin}
We had to develop an ontology from scratch which could capture all of unique information found in international interactions.<br><br>
:::

![](images/icbe_litreview.png)

### Human Interface

<p>

::: {.column-margin}
The downside of a large ontology is coder fatigue.<br><br>

Our solution was an interactive GUI that presented questions only as they became relevant based on previous answers.
:::

## Cell Phone Communications

![](images/CellClustersInIvoryCoast.png)

Figure 4. Each cell tower is marked with a symbol representing the network community computed for it. These network communities appear to follow primary language boundaries (for 60 dialects in Cˆote d'Ivoire, which are grouped into 4 major languages indicated by boundary colors) more closely than political or geographic boundaries (not shown). Further, areas with high population density (Abidjan inset) show clustering at a neighborhood level which exceeds the resolution of existing language data.
